title: Chapter 3 Review - Practice & Application
description: Review and practice everything from Chapter 3

content.instructions: Test your knowledge of numbers, nouns, use of the prefix 'ja' and introductions from lessons 6-9.

exercises.question: Translate this: 'Omondi nigi oguyo'
exercises.explanation: The word 'oguyo' means 'butterfly'. It's plural is 'oguche'.

exercises.question: Translate this: 'Owada nigi gari to oting'o ring'o'
options: My relative has a car and he is carrying meat
My friend has some meat that he is carrying
My friend has a car and he is carrying meat
My relative has some meat and he left it in the car.

exercises.question: What is the opposite of 'akuche nitie.'?
exercises.explanation: 'Nitie' means 'to be present'. The opposite is 'onge' which means 'to be absent'.

exercises.question: How would you say: 'I don't have money'?
exercises.explanation: 'Aonge' means 'I don't have' or 'I am not present with'.

exercises.question: What is the plural of the word 'athero'? ('athero' means 'an arrow')
exercises.explanation: It ends in 'r' followed by a vowel so it's plural takes the 'che' ending

exercises.question: The word 'gol' is a loan word from English meaning 'goal' as in a football match. How would you say '5 goals'?
What do you call a female child born while it is raining?
What is the luo word for 'evening'
exercises.explanation: 'Odhiambo' means 'evening'. Children born at this time are named 'Odhiambo' or 'Adhiambo'.

exercises.question: The verb 'biro' means 'to come'. How do you say 'You (plural) are coming'?
exercises.explanation: You add the pronoun suffix 'U' to the beginning of the verb.

exercises.question: The verb 'puonjo' means 'to teach'. How would you say: 'I am teaching you (plural)?'
exercises.explanation: Add the pronoun suffix 'u' to the end of the verb to show the object i.e the person being taught.

exercises.question: The verb 'puonjo' means 'to teach'. How would you say: 'I am teaching them?'
exercises.explanation: Add the pronoun suffix 'gi' to the end of the verb to show the object i.e the person being taught.

exercises.question: What do you call a child born during weeding season?
exercises.explanation: From the verb 'doyo' which means 'to weed'

content.instructions: Using what you've learned in this chapter, send a quick text to your friend. Tell them what you're doing and name a few random things that you have in this moment.
prompts: Start by sharing what you're doing: 'Asomo' (I am reading)
Mention three things that you have: 'Antie gi buk, gi sim, gi pesa. ' (I have a book, and a phone, and money)
content.example: Asomo. Antie gi buk, gi sim, gi pesa.

content.instructions: Listen to the audio clip and answer the questions below. You can replay the audio up to 3 times.
content.transcript: An Otieno. Adhi limogi. Gin be gidhi dala. Nyathi maduong' otedo maber.
content.translation: I am Otieno. I'm going to visit them. They are also going home. The big child cooked well.

questions.question: What is the speaker's name?
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'An Otieno' meaning 'I am Otieno'

questions.question: Where is the speaker going?
questions.explanation: 'Adhi limogi' means 'I'm going to visit them'

questions.question: Who cooked well?
questions.explanation: 'Nyathi maduong' otedo maber' means 'The big child cooked well'

content.congratulations: Excellent work! You've completed Chapter 3 and are well on your way to speaking Dholuo like a native.
content.summary: In this chapter you learned: more on nouns, the verbs 'to have' and 'to be' and how to conjugate verbs in the present tense, and how Luos name their children.
content.next_steps: Ready for Chapter 4? You'll learn about asking questions, tenses, and more.
